awd_titl_txt: Volatile Product Formation and Atmospheric Lifetimes of Biogenic Organic Aerosols
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is focused on developing a better understanding of how reactive carbon evolves in the atmosphere.  Highly controlled environmental chamber experiments will be conducted to evaluate the aging chemistry of organic aerosol.  Experiments will help to determine the extent to which aerosol aging depends on particle characteristics (such as liquid water, inorganic composition, pH, organic composition, and surface area) as well as environmental conditions (such as temperature and relative humidity).

The objectives of the research are to: (1) Quantify the production of oxygenated volatile organic compounds (OVOC) and the oxidative lifetimes from hydroxyl radical (OH)-initiated oxidation of suspended organic aerosol (OA); (2) Characterize how physical, chemical, and environmental parameters affect the OH lifetime and OVOC production of the biogenic OA under investigation; (3) Investigate the difference in mechanism between aqueous OH and heterogeneous OH oxidation; and (4) Study the effects of direct photolysis on OA.  

This research will provide important new data inputs and constraints for atmospheric models that simulate reactive carbon in the atmosphere.  The results are expected to significantly improve the understanding of how semi-volatiles and particles affect climate, air quality, and health.

por.por_cntn:
Aerosol particles (made up of organic compounds, salts and other inorganics, and water) can float around in the atmosphere for days or weeks. During that time they become more wet or dry, and chemically react under sunlight (photochemical aging). This photochemical aging can add or remove organic mass from the aerosol, and form volatile products that leave the particle phase into the gas phase. This project studies the process of photochemical aging in particle water for compounds that are abundantly found on atmospheric aerosols. A particular focus is on the volatile compounds formic and acetic acids, and on the aging of aerosol-phase species that are abundant in biogenic (primarily forested) areas. This is because formic acid and acetic acids exert considerable control over aerosol-cloud interactions and aerosol acidity, which has important chemistry and climate effects; yet, satellite data show that there is about twice as much atmospheric abundance as can be accounted for using all of the known chemistry. At the same time, the atmospheric models predict too much organic aerosol mass over biogenic regions. Major models do not currently consider photochemical aging of aerosols as a “sink” or removal process of organic aerosol mass and a “source” of volatile compounds like formic and acetic acids.

This project led to a number of important outcomes:

(1)   We successfully synthesized and purified several structurally-diverse organic compounds that exist in biogenic aerosols for further study. These compounds are unavailable to buy commercially so most of the fundamental information related to their chemistry is still unknown. The compounds we synthesized include poly-alcohols, organic hydroxy nitrates, organic hydroxy sulfates, hydroxy alkenes and hydroxy acids.

(2)   We reported the first absolute yields of formic acid and acetic acids from the photochemical aging of authentic compounds in biogenic aerosols. These yields are large; we found that the studied 5-carbon molecules produced about 2-3 formic acids and 1-2 acetic acids per molecule. Compared to the reactions in the gas phase, photochemical reactions in the aerosol water has many times more the potential to produce formic and acetic acids. Previous studies have shown that gas-phase reactions alone can not reconcile the “missing” formic acid, precisely because yields are too low in the gas phase, and thus require consideration of the aqueous particle phase.

(3)   We reported nine new rate coefficients for the reaction of hydroxyl (OH) radical with aerosol-phase compounds that were synthesized in (1). This addresses the large gap in knowledge for understanding the rate coefficients of photochemical reactions in the aerosol water, which must be understood before we can insert the photochemical reactions of aerosol phase compounds into atmospheric models.

(4)   We studied the volatile organic formation from the photooxidation of 1,2-dihydroxy isoprene (1,2-DHI) because it is produced in the atmosphere in large quantities in biogenic areas; however, its chemical fate has not been comprehensively studied. We reported two new rate coefficients for the reactions of 1,2-DHI with OH radicals and ozone, which are both quite rapid. We found this reaction made a number of volatile compounds as well, including formic and acetic acids. Some of the product yields of 1,2-DHI are different than expected based on predictions based on other compounds.

(5)   We have added four photochemical aging reactions (of some of the more abundant species) studied in this work into the global chemical transport model GEOS-Chem; this is the first time that this model included photochemical reactions of aerosols. This change alone has addressed two significant model-measurement disagreement issues, it decreased the aerosol mass overestimation by 50-100% and increased the formic acid underestimation by 30% in the Southeast United States area (the area with one of the highest discrepancies). There are numerous more organic molecules that can be added to models in the future.

 

This project has produced new fundamental insights on chemical kinetics, yields, and mechanisms regarding biogenic aerosol-phase compounds and reported these insights to the atmospheric chemistry literature. These insights have improved the model understanding of atmospheric composition and aerosol-cloud climate interactions. The project resulted in the publication of  three peer-reviewed paper (with one more about to be submitted) and several podium presentations. We made the data publicly available on the ICARUS (https://icarus.ucdavis.edu) and Dryad (https://datadryad.org) repositories. This project also provided opportunities for two female undergraduate students to lead their own research projects, which led to two Honor’s Theses, and publish their findings in the peer-reviewed scientific literature. The project also provided opportunities for two post-doctoral level researchers to advance their careers by independently leading projects, mentoring younger scientists, presenting their research at national conferences, publishing their data in the scientific literature, and formally teach classes using their own research findings. Finally, the project significantly aided in the laboratory and career development of the PI, who is an junior faculty member at UC Davis.
